title: Physical Pendulum - changing density and length

content.description: Two unform rods <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are suspended from their ends. When Rod <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are displaced slightly from equilibrium, they oscillate with periods <math alttext="T sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. Rod <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has uniform linear mass density <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> and length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>. Rod <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"> <mn>2</mn> </math> has uniform linear mass density <math alttext="2 lambda" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>λ</mi></math>, and length <math alttext="2 L" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math>, as shown in the figure.
content.question: What is the value of <math alttext="the fraction with numerator T sub 2, and denominator T sub 1" overflow="scroll"> <mfrac> <msub> <mi>T</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <msub> <mi>T</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> </mfrac> </math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator the square root of 2" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
